[[Ed Reed]] ''(2nd team)'' | uniform = File:AFCN-Uniform-BAL.PNG }} The '''2009 Baltimore Ravens season''' is the [[Baltimore Ravens|franchise's]] [[List of Baltimore Ravens seasons|14th season]] as a team in the [[National Football League]] (NFL). The franchise entered the season off an 11â5 record in their [[2008 Baltimore Ravens season|previous season]], a playoff berth, but a loss in the [[AFC Championship|American Football Conference (AFC) Championship]] game against the eventual [[Super Bowl XLIII]] champions, the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]. The Ravens recorded nine victories to seven losses, although they were unable to win the [[AFC North]] division title. However, due to various playoff clinching scenarios in the AFC, the Ravens were able to clinch a [[NFL Wild card|wild card]] [[2009-10 NFL Playoffs|playoff]] berth against the [[New England Patriots]], which they won. They, however, lost in the AFC playoffs divisional round against the [[Indianapolis Colts]]; with this loss, the 2009 season came to an end for the Ravens. For [[head coach]] [[John Harbaugh]], this was his second year with the franchise, compiling a overall record of 20â12 in the regular season. {{TOClimit|3}} ==Offseason== [[Rex Ryan]], a longtime fixture on the Ravens' sidelines, departed for New York to become the [[New York Jets]] head coach after the Ravens fell to the Steelers in the [[National Football League playoffs, 2008-09|2008 AFC Championship]] game. Other notable offseason departures include linebacker [[Bart Scott]] and safety [[Jim Leonhard]], both of whom left Baltimore to follow Rex Ryan to New York, and longtime [[placekicker]] [[Matt Stover]]. On March 5, 2009, Stover told reporters that the Ravens were "going in a different direction".http://games.espn.go.com/ffl/resources/playernews?playerId=129 When Stover's tenure ended with the Ravens, the team severed ties with one of its two remaining players from the Ravens' first season in 1996; the other being [[Ray Lewis (American football)|Ray Lewis]]. ===2009 NFL Draft=== The Baltimore Ravens had six selections going into in the [[2009 NFL Draft]], which was held in [[Radio City Music Hall]] in [[New York City]], [[New York]] on April 25 and April 26, 2009. {| class="wikitable sortable sortable" |- ! They will also face the [[Indianapolis Colts]] from the [[AFC South]] Division and the [[New England Patriots]] from the [[AFC East]] Division based on the 2002 â 2009 NFL scheduling formula because of their second place finish in the AFC North Division.{{cite web|url=http://www.footballinjuries.com/rotation.htm |title=Explanation of new NFL Scheduling Formula|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hg3jPZxu|archivedate=2009-06-20|deadurl=no|accessdate=2009-04-27}} The Ravens have the fifth easiest strength of schedule in the NFL based on its aforementioned opponents' win to loss ratio from the [[2008 NFL season|2008 season]], with its opponents winning 43.8% of their scheduled games in 2008.http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/draft09/news/story?id=4027503 ===Schedule=== The 2009 NFL schedule was released on April 14, 2009.http://www.nfl.com/schedules/release '''COLOR KEY:''' :{{colorbox|#ddffdd}} The Ravens won the game. :{{colorbox|#ffdddd}} The Ravens lost the game. {| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto; font-size:92%;" |- ! rowspan="2" | Week ! rowspan="2" | Date ! rowspan="2" | Kickoff ([[Eastern Time Zone|ET]]) ! rowspan="2" | Opponent ! colspan="2" | Results ! rowspan="2" | Game Site ! rowspan="2" | TV ! rowspan="2" | NFL Recap |- ! They hosted the Kansas City Chiefs, who struggled to a franchise-worst 2â14 record in 2008. The Ravens dominated time of possession and offensive production throughout the game, but their special teams miscues made the game much closer than the score would indicate. The Ravens found the end zone half way through the first quarter for their first touchdown of the season when Flacco found Willis McGahee for a 3 yard touchdown pass. The Ravens would later increase their advantage with a Steven Hauschka field goal. In the second quarter, a special teams miscue led to Chiefs safety Jon McGraw blocking a Sam Koch punt into the end zone, where he recovered for a touchdown. Early in the third quarter, Derrick Johnson intercepted an errant Joe Flacco pass and returned it to the Ravens 3 yard line. Chiefs quarterback Brodie Croyle found standout receiver Dwayne Bowe for a touchdown three plays later. The Ravens would respond with an 11 play, five minute drive capped off by a 9 yard touchdown to Todd Heap. After trading touchdowns halfway through the fourth quarter, the Ravens defense forced a turnover on downs, and the Ravens offense capitalized with a Le'Ron McClain 1 yard touchdown run. The Ravens would add an additional touchdown from McGahee in the final minute of the game to open their season with a 38 â 24 win, and the second win in as many home openers. With the win, not only do the Ravens improve to 1â0, they are the only team in the AFC North to win their home opener on Kickoff Sunday; the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Tennessee Titans 13 â 10 on Kickoff Night the Thursday prior. ====Week 2: at San Diego Chargers==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="background:#BE00D2"|Week Two: the Ravens in their home debut in San Diego after a narrow escape in the second of two [[2009 NFL season|AFL 50th Anniversary]]-themed division rivalry Monday Night matchups against the Raiders in Oakland. The Chargers jumped out to an early lead when a blown coverage led to an easy 81 yard touchdown pass from Philip Rivers to Darren Sproles. The Ravens answered with Willis McGahee on a 5 yard touchdown run, but the Chargers would increase their advantage on a Nate Kaeding field goal. The offensive display would continue in the second quarter, but the Ravens touchdowns were only answered by Chargers field goals. McGahee found the end zone a second time to take the lead 14 â 10, but the Chargers pulled within one on the second Kaeding field goal. Flacco then found Kelley Washington for Flacco's first touchdown pass of the day and Washington's first touchdown reception as a Raven just inside the 2-minute halftime warning. Rivers led the Chargers down the field in an attempt to answer, but the drive stalled and had to settle for the third of four Kaeding field goals. In the second half, both defenses stiffened. Todd Heap would get his second touchdown catch of the season from Flacco from 9 yards out, but the Chargers responded with a 35 yard touchdown catch from Vincent Jackson. Late in the fourth quarter, interceptions from Flacco and Rivers led to trading field goals. After a Ravens punt, Rivers led the Chargers all the way down to the Ravens 15. The Chargers went for the first down on fourth down to go for the win, but Sproles was stopped by Ray Lewis five yards in the backfield, allowing the Ravens to run the clock out. With the win, not only do the Ravens improve to 2â0, the Ravens take sole possession of first place in the AFC North. ====Week 3: vs. Cleveland Browns==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! (Coincidentally, the Bengals host the Steelers in divisional play in week three as well.) Although this was the third consecutive high scoring game for the Ravens, this was not a close contest. The Ravens struck early on the first of two touchdown runs from Willis McGahee, and would increase their advantage on a Hauschka field goal. In the second quarter, after another Hauschka field goal, McGahee found the end zone again. His second rushing TD leads the NFL with five. Although the Browns wanted to prove they were up to the challenge of contending with a quality football team, miscues thoroughly undid the Browns as quarterbacks Derek Anderson and Brady Quinn combined for four interceptions. Quinn was benched at the half in favor of Anderson, but Anderson was no better than his maligned counterpart. The third quarter only saw another touchdown for the Ravens, but was a special one for Ray Rice, as it was his first career NFL touchdown. The final minutes of the third quarter also saw the Browns longest drive of the day, but as time expired in the third quarter, the Browns were stopped short of the end zone. The fourth quarter opened with the Browns only points of the game on a field goal from Billy Cundiff, a free-agent signee since kicker Phil Dawson was inactive due to a leg injury. The final points of the contest came on the third Anderson interception, which was Ed Reed's first of the season. Flacco's touchdown was not only the longest of the season for him to date, but was the only passing touchdown all day. He hit a wide open Derrick Mason after a blown coverage in the Browns secondary for a 72 yard touchdown. With the win, the Ravens improve to 3â0 and improve to 1â0 in the AFC North. ====Week 4: at New England Patriots==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- Ravens flew to [[Gillette Stadium]] for a Week 4 battle with the [[New England Patriots]]. After Patriots kicker [[Stephen Gostkowski]] got a 32-yard field goal in the first quarter, Baltimore got into the game with quarterback [[Joe Flacco]] hooking up with wide receiver [[Derrick Mason]] on a 20-yard touchdown pass. In the second quarter, New England came back with quarterback [[Tom Brady]]'s 1-yard touchdown run and running back [[Sammy Morris]]' 12-yard touchdown run. The Ravens would reply in the third quarter with defensive end [[Terrell Suggs]] sacking Brady, causing a fumble which rolled into the Patriots' endzone, where defensive end [[Dwan Edwards]] would land on it for a touchdown. New England would come right back with Brady's 14-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Randy Moss]]. Baltimore would play some catch-up in the fourth quarter as Flacco found running back [[Willis McGahee]] on a 13-yard touchdown pass, but the Patriots willingly replied with Gostkowski's 33-yard field goal. Flacco would lead a last-minute drive, but New England's stiffened and came away with the win. With the tough loss, the Ravens fell to 3â1. ====Week 5: vs. Cincinnati Bengals==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="background:#BE00D2"|Week {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Bengals''' |R1=0 |R2=3 |R3=7 |R4=7 |RT= |Home=Ravens |H1=0 |H2=7 |H3=0 |H4=7 |HT= }} Hoping to rebound from their tough road loss to the Patriots, the Ravens went home for a Week 5 AFC North duel with the [[Cincinnati Bengals]]. The winner would take the lead in the division after five weeks. After a scoreless first quarter, Baltimore's defense went to work in the second quarter with safety [[Ed Reed]] returning an interception 52 yards for a touchdown. The Bengals would answer with a 32-yard field goal from kicker [[Shayne Graham]]. Near the end of the third quarter, Cincinnati would take the lead on a 28-yard touchdown run from running back [[Cedric Benson]]. The Ravens would respond in the fourth quarter as quarterback [[Joe Flacco]] hooked up with running back [[Ray Rice]] 48-yard touchdown pass. However, late in the game, the Bengals would deliver the final strike as quarterback [[Carson Palmer]] completed a 20-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Andre Caldwell]]. Baltimore tried to rally, but an interception from cornerback [[Leon Hall]] eliminated any chance of a comeback. With the loss, the Ravens fell to 3â2. Also, the defense's 40-game streak of keeping a single rusher under 100 yards was snapped. The last time that Baltimore allowed a 100-yard rusher was Dec. 10, 2006 against the Chiefs' [[Larry Johnson (American football)|Larry Johnson]]. ====Week 6: at Minnesota Vikings==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="background:#BE00D2"|Week Six: Baltimore Ravens vs. Minnesota Vikings â Summary |- | {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * '''Game time:''' 1:00 PM EDT * '''Game weather:''' None (Domed Stadium) * '''Referee:''' [[Mike Carey (American football)|Mike Carey]] ;First Quarter *MIN â [[Visanthe Shiancoe|Shiancoe]] 19 yard TD reception from [[Brett Favre|Favre]] ([[Ryan Longwell|Longwell]] PAT) â 11:25 *MIN â [[Bernard Berrian|Berrian]] 4 yard TD reception from Favre (Longwell PAT) â 6:16 ;Second Quarter *BAL â [[Steven Hauschka|Hauschka]] 29 yard FG â 0:02 ;Third Quarter *MIN â Longwell 40 yard FG â 7:16 *BAL â [[Ray Rice|Rice]] 22 yard TD run (Hauschka PAT) â 4:13 *MIN â Longwell 22 yard FG â 2:05 ;Fourth Quarter *MIN â Shiancoe 1 yard TD reception from Favre (Longwell PAT) â 10:08 *BAL â [[Mark J. Humphrey Metrodome]] for a Week 6 interconference duel with the [[Minnesota Vikings]]. Baltimore would trail in the first quarter as Vikings quarterback [[Brett Favre]] completed a 19-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Visanthe Shiancoe]] and a 4-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Bernard Berrian]]. Afterwards, the Ravens would snag the only points of the second quarter with kicker [[Steven Hauschka]] making a 29-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Minnesota would extend its lead as kicker [[Ryan Longwell]] nailed a 40-yard field goal. Baltimore would come right back into the game with running back [[Ray Rice]]'s 22-yard touchdown run, but Longwell helped out the Vikings with a 22-yard field goal. In a nerve-racking fourth quarter, Minnesota increased its lead with Favre finding Shiancoe again on a 1-yard touchdown run. The Ravens would respond with quarterback [[Joe Flacco]]'s 32-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Mark Clayton (American football, born 1982)|Mark Clayton]]. After Longwell gave the Vikings a 29-yard field goal, Baltimore would take the lead as Flacco completed a 12-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Derrick Mason]] and Rice getting a 33-yard touchdown run. Minnesota would regain the lead as Longwell booted a 31-yard field goal. Flacco would get the Ravens into scoring range, but Hauschka's 44-yard field goal attempt sailed wide left, preserving the Vikings' so-far perfect season. With the loss, Baltimore went into its bye week at 3â3. This also marked the first time that the Ravens defense allowed back-to-back 100-yard rushers since 2005 (Bengals' [[Rudi Johnson]] & Texans' [[Domanick Williams]]). ====Week 7: Bye Week==== ====Week 8: vs. Denver Broncos==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="background:#BE00D2"|Week Eight: Denver Broncos vs. Baltimore Ravens â Summary |- | {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * '''Game time:''' 1:00 PM EST * '''Game weather:''' 56Â°F (Cloudy) * '''Referee:''' [[Walt Coleman]] ;First Quarter *BAL â [[Steven Hauschka|Hauschka]] 43 yard FG â 0:56 ;Second Quarter *BAL â Hauschka 35 yard FG â 4:58 ;Third Quarter *BAL â [[Lardarius Webb]] 95 yard kickoff TD return (Hauschka PAT) â 14:46 *DEN â [[Knowshon Moreno|Moreno]] 1 yard TD run ([[Matt Prater|Prater]] PAT) â 9:46 *BAL â Hauschka 31 yard FG â 4:55 ;Fourth Quarter *BAL â [[Derrick Mason|Mason]] 20 yard TD reception from [[Joe Flacco|Flacco]] (Hauschka PAT) â 13:07 *BAL â [[Ray Rice|Rice]] 7 yard TD run (Hauschka PAT) â 1:59 {{col-2}} * '''Game attendance:''' 71,132 at [[M&T Bank Stadium]] in [[Baltimore, Maryland]] * '''TV announcers:''' ([[NFL on CBS|CBS]]) [[Greg Gumbel]] and [[Dan Dierdorf]] * '''Game coverage:''' [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54570/BLT_Gamebook.pdf NFL Game Summary] ;Leading Passers *BAL â [[Joe Flacco]] â 20 comp â 25 att â 175 yds â 1 TD â 0 INT *DEN â [[Kyle Orton]] â 23 comp â 37 att â 152 yds â 0 TD â 0 INT ;Leading Rushers *BAL â [[Ray Rice]] â 23 rush â 84 yds â 1 TD *DEN â [[Knowshon Moreno]] â 10 rush â 39 yds â 1 TD ;Leading Receivers *BAL â [[Kelley Washington]] â 4 rec â 58 yds â 0 TD *DEN â [[Jabar Gaffney]] â 3 rec â 43 yds â 0 TD ;Leading Tacklers *BAL â [[Fabian Washington]] & [[Ray Lewis (American football)|Ray Lewis]] â 6 tackles each *DEN â [[D. Williams]] & [[Andra Davis]] â 8 tackles each {{col-end}} |} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Broncos |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=7 |R4=0 |RT=7 |Home='''Ravens''' |H1=3 |H2=3 |H3=10 |H4=14 |HT=30 }} Coming off their bye week, the Ravens went home for a Week 8 duel with the undefeated [[Denver Broncos]]. Baltimore took flight in the first half with kicker [[Steven Hauschka]] nailing a 43-yard field goal in the first quarter and a 35-yard field goal in the second quarter. The Ravens would immediately make their domination felt in the third quarter as rookie cornerback [[Lardarius Webb]] returned the second half's opening kickoff 95 yards for a touchdown. The Broncos would get on the board with running back [[Knowshon Moreno]] getting a 1-yard touchdown run, yet Baltimore answered with Hauschka booting a 31-yard field goal. Afterwards, the Ravens closed the game out in the fourth quarter as quarterback [[Joe Flacco]] found wide receiver [[Derrick Mason]] on a 20-yard touchdown pass, while running back [[Ray Rice]] got a 7-yard touchdown run. With the win, Baltimore improved to 4â3. ====Week 9: at Cincinnati Bengals==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="background:#BE00D2"|Week Nine: Baltimore Ravens vs. Cincinnati Bengals â Summary |- | {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * '''Game time:''' 1:00 PM EST * '''Game weather:''' 67Â°F (Sunny) * '''Referee:''' [[Alberto Riveron]] ;First Quarter *CIN â [[Andre Caldwell|Caldwell]] 6 yard TD reception from [[Carson Palmer|Palmer]] ([[Shayne Graham|Graham]] PAT) â 8:55 *CIN â [[Cedric Benson|Benson]] 1 yard TD run (Graham PAT) â 2:23 ;Second Quarter *CIN â Graham 23 yard FG â 7:45 ;Third Quarter *No Scoring ;Fourth Quarter *BAL â [[Ray Rice|Rice]] 2 yard TD run ([[Steven Hauschka|Hauschka]] PAT) â 12:54 {{col-2}} * '''Game attendance:''' 64,313 at [[Paul Brown Stadium]] in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]] * '''TV announcers:''' ([[NFL on CBS|CBS]]) [[Dick Enberg]] and [[Dan Fouts]] * '''Game coverage:''' [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54585/CIN_Gamebook.pdf NFL Game Summary] ;Leading Passers *CIN â [[Carson Palmer]] â 20 comp â 33 att â 224 yds â 1 TD â 0 INT *BAL â [[Joe Flacco]] â 18 comp â 32 att â 195 yds â 0 TD â 2 INT ;Leading Rushers *CIN â [[Cedric Benson]] â 34 rush â 117 yds â 1 TD *BAL â [[Ray Rice]] â 12 rush â 48 yds â 1 TD ;Leading Receivers *CIN â [[Laveranues Coles]] â 6 rec â 72 yds â 0 TD *BAL â Ray Rice â 8 rec â 87 yds â 0 TD ;Leading Tacklers *CIN â [[Chinedum Ndukwe]] â 8 tackles â 1 solo *BAL â [[Dwan Edwards]] â 6 tackles â 2 solo {{col-end}} |} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Ravens |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=7 |RT=7 |Home='''Bengals''' |H1=14 |H2=3 |H3=0 |H4=0 |HT=17 }} Coming off their dominating home win over the Broncos, the Ravens flew to [[Paul Brown Stadium]] for a Week 9 AFC North rematch with the [[Cincinnati Bengals]]. Baltimore would trail in the first quarter as Bengals quarterback [[Carson Palmer]] completed a 6-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Andre Caldwell]], followed by running back [[Cedric Benson]] getting a 1-yard touchdown run. Cincinnati would increase their lead in the second quarter as kicker [[Shayne Graham]] booted a 23-yard field goal. After a scoreless third quarter, the Ravens got on the board with a 2-yard touchdown run from running back [[Ray Rice]]. However, the Bengals' defense would stop any further progress from Baltimore. With the loss, the Ravens fell to 4â4. ====Week 10: at Cleveland Browns==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="background:#BE00D2"|Week Ten: Baltimore Ravens vs. Cleveland Browns â Summary |- | {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * '''Game time:''' 8:30 PM EDT * '''Game weather:''' 46F (Chilly) * '''Referee:''' [[Carl Cheffers]] ;First Quarter * No scoring ;Second Quarter * No scoring ;Third Quarter * BAL â [[Ray Rice|Rice]] 13 yard TD run ([[Steven Hauschka|Hauschka]] PAT) â 12:35 * BAL â [[Dawan Landry|Landry]] 41 yard interception return TD (Hauschka PAT blocked) â 12:20 * BAL â Hauschka 44 yard FG â 7:25 ;Fourth Quarter * No scoring {{col-2}} * '''Game attendance:''' 69,023 at [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]] in [[Cleveland, Ohio]] * '''TV announcers:''' ([[Monday Night Football|ESPN]]) [[Mike Tirico]], [[Ron Jaworski]], [[Jon Gruden]] and [[Michelle Tafoya]] * '''Game coverage:''' [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54610/CLV_Gamebook.pdf NFL Game Summary] ;Leading Passers *CLE â [[Brady Quinn]] â 13 comp â 31 att â 99 yds â 0 TD â 2 INT *BAL â [[Joe Flacco]] â 13 comp â 18 att â 155 yds â 0 TD â 0 INT ;Leading Rushers *CLE â [[Jamal Lewis]] â 10 rush â 36 yds â 0 TD *BAL â [[Ray Rice]] â 20 rush â 89 yds â 1 TD ;Leading Receivers *CLE â [[Mohamed Massaquoi]] â 1 rec â 30 yds â 0 TD *BAL â [[Derrick Mason]] â 3 rec â 78 yds â 0 TD ;Leading Tacklers *CLE â [[David Bowens]] â 9 tackles â 7 solo *BAL â [[Ray Lewis (American football)|Ray Lewis]] â 7 tackles â 5 solo {{col-end}} |} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Ravens''' |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=16 |R4=0 |RT=16 |Home=Browns |H1=0 |H2=0 |H3=0 |H4=0 |HT=0 }} Hoping to rebound from their season-sweeping losses to the Bengals, the Ravens flew to [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]] for a Week 10 Monday night duel with their AFC North rival, the [[Cleveland Browns]]. After a scoreless first half, Baltimore would acquire all of their points in the third quarter. It began with running back [[Ray Rice]] getting a 13-yard touchdown run, safety [[Dawan Landry]] returning an interception 48 yards for a touchdown, and kicker [[Steven Hauschka]] booting a 44-yard field goal. Afterwards, the defense would consistently shutdown the Browns' inept offense. With the win, the Ravens improved to 5â4. ====Week 11: vs. Indianapolis Colts==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="background:#BE00D2"|Week Eleven: Indianapolis Colts vs. Baltimore Ravens â Summary |- | {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * '''Game time:''' 1:00 PM EST * '''Game weather:''' 56Â°F (Sunny) * '''Referee:''' [[John Parry (American football official)|John Parry]] ;First Quarter *IND â [[Dallas Clark|Clark]] 3 yard TD reception from [[Peyton Manning|Manning]] ([[Matt Stover|Stover]] kick) â 11:24 *BAL â [[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] 46 yard FG â 5:09 *BAL â Cundiff 44 yard FG â 4:01 ;Second Quarter *BAL â Cundiff 38 yard FG â 4:43 *IND â [[Joseph Addai|Addai]] 5 yard TD run (Stover kick) â 1:23 *BAL â Cundiff 36 yard FG â 0:02 ;Third Quarter *No Scoring ;Fourth Quarter *BAL â Cundiff 20 yard FG â 10:12 *IND â Stover 25 yard FG â 7:02 {{col-2}} * '''Game attendance:''' 71,320 at [[M&T Bank Stadium]] in [[Baltimore, Maryland]] * '''TV announcers:''' ([[NFL on CBS|CBS]]) [[Greg Gumbel]] and [[Dan Dierdorf]] * '''Game coverage:''' [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54612/BLT_Gamebook.pdf NFL Game Summary] ;Leading Passers *BAL â [[Joe Flacco]] â 23 comp â 35 att â 256 yards â 0 TD â 1 INT *IND â [[Peyton Manning]] â 22 comp â 31 att â 299 yds â 1 TD â 2 INT ;Leading Rushers *BAL â [[Ray Rice]] â 20 rush, 71 yards *IND â [[Joseph Addai]] â 19 rush â 74 yds â 1 TD ;Leading Receivers *BAL â [[Derrick Mason]] â 9 rec, 142 yds *IND â [[Pierre GarÃ§on]] â 6 rec, 108 yds ;Leading Tacklers *BAL â [[Ray Lewis]] â 8 tackles â 4 solo *IND â [[Gary Brackett]] â 9 tackles â 8 solo {{col-end}} |} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Colts''' |R1=7 |R2=7 |R3=0 |R4=3 |RT=17 |Home=Ravens |H1=6 |H2=6 |H3=0 |H4=3 |HT=15 }} Coming off their shutout road win over the Browns, the Ravens went home for a Week 11 duel with the [[Indianapolis Colts]]. Baltimore would trail in the first quarter as Colts quarterback [[Peyton Manning]] threw a 1-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Dallas Clark]]. The Ravens would answer with recently-signed kicker [[Billy Cundiff]] (after [[Steven Hauschka]] was cut) making a 46-yard and a 44-yard field goal. Baltimore would take the lead in the second quarter with Cundiff's 38-yard field goal, but Indianapolis would answer with a 5-yard touchdown run from running back [[Joseph Addai]]. The Ravens would close out the half with Cundiff nailing a 36-yard field goal. After a scoreless third quarter, Baltimore regained the lead again in the fourth quarter with a 20-yard field goal from Cundiff, but the Colts would get the last laugh as former Ravens kicker [[Matt Stover]] booted a 25-yard field goal. With the loss, Baltimore fell to 5â5. ====Week 12: vs. Pittsburgh Steelers==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="background:#BE00D2"|Week Twelve: Pittsburgh Steelers vs. Baltimore Ravens â Summary |- | {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * '''Game time:''' 8:20 PM EST * '''Game weather:''' 61Â°F (Clear) * '''Referee:''' [[Ed Hochuli]] ;First Quarter *BAL-[[Willis McGahee|McGahee]] 2 yard TD run ([[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] PAT) â 2:00 ;Second Quarter *PIT-[[Santonio Holmes|Holmes]] 33 yard TD pass from [[Dennis Dixon|Dixon]] ([[Jeff Reed (American football)|Reed]] PAT) â 3:37 *BAL- [[Derrick Mason|Mason]] 10 yard TD pass from [[Joe Flacco|Flacco]] (Cundiff PAT) â 2:26 ;Third Quarter *PIT- Jeff Reed 44 yard FG â 1:40 ;Fourth Quarter *PIT- Dixon 24 yard TD run (Reed PAT) â 5:09 *BAL- Cundiff 24 yard FG â 4:33 ;Overtime *BAL- Cundiff 29 yard FG â 3:23 {{col-2}} * '''Game attendance:''' 71,314 at [[M&T Bank Stadium]] in [[Baltimore, Maryland]] * '''TV announcers:''' ([[NBC Sunday Night Football|NBC]]) [[Al Michaels]], [[Cris Collinsworth]] & [[Andrea Kremer]] * '''Game coverage:''' ;Leading Passers *BAL â [[Joe Flacco]] 23/39, 289 yards, 1 TD *PIT â [[Dennis Dixon]] 12/26, 145 yards, 1 TD, 1 INT ;Leading Rushers *BAL â [[Ray Rice]] 19 carries, 88 yards *PIT â [[Rashard Mendenhall]] 24 carries, 95 yards ;Leading Receivers *BAL â [[Mark Clayton (American football, born 1982)|Mark Clayton]] 7 catches, 129 yards *PIT â [[Santonio Holmes]] 6 catches, 74 yards, 1 TD ;Leading Tacklers *BAL â [[Dawan Landry]] 8 tackles, 8 solo *PIT â [[William Gay (cornerback)|William Gay]] 8 tackles, 8 solo {{col-end}} |} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Steelers |R1=0||R2=7||R3=3||R4=7||R5=0||RT=17 |Home='''Ravens''' |H1=7||H2=7||H3=0||H4=3||H5=3||HT=20 }} Following a close loss to the [[Indianapolis Colts|Colts]] the prior week, the much-hated Steelers came to town for a rematch of last year's AFC Championship Game. Steelers starting QB [[Ben Roethlisberger]], who suffered a concussion in the previous week's overtime loss to the [[Kansas City Chiefs|Chiefs]] did not start, and was the designated 3rd (emergency) quarterback. Backup [[Charlie Batch]] also was hurt in that game, which left 2nd-year QB [[Dennis Dixon]], who previously had one pass in his NFL career, to start. The Steelers received the opening kickoff, but went three-and-out. On the ensuing possession, the Ravens drove down the field with ease, capping off their drive with a touchdown run by Willis McGahee. In the second quarter, Dixon hit WR [[Santonio Holmes]] on a play-action pass for a 33 yard TD, tying the game. The Ravens answered on the following drive, with a 52-yard strike from Joe Flacco to Mark Clayton, setting up a 10-yard touchdown pass to Derrick Mason. In the third quarter, on the Ravens opening possession, Mark Clayton made a 9 yard reception but fumbled the ball. The ball was kicked 20 yards towards the Steelers endzone by a Pittsburgh player, but recovered by Tyrone Carter. The Steelers drove, but were held to a field goal by Jeff Reed. Later in the 4th quarter, Joe Flacco was sacked by [[Lawrence Timmons]] and fumbled the ball, recovered by the Steelers near midfield. The drive resulted in a 24 yard run on a QB option by Dixon, giving the Steelers their first lead of the night. On the Ravens next possession, things were looking bad when the offense was facing a 3rd and 22 with around 3 minutes left. Joe Flacco completed a pass to Derrick Mason for 17 yards, leaving John Harbaugh with a critical decision. Harbaugh opted to go for it, and Joe Flacco found Ray Rice for a 44-yard reception, setting the Ravens up inside the Steeler 10 yard line with less than 2 minutes left. Billy Cundiff tied the game with a 24 yard field goal. On the following Steeler possession, Dennis Dixon was nearly intercepted by Lardarius Webb. The Steelers were forced to punt, giving the ball back to the Ravens with about 1:30 left in the game. A very good punt return into Steeler territory by [[Chris Carr (American football)|Chris Carr]] was wiped off by a block in the back. Despite the setback, the Ravens managed to drive to the Steeler 40 yard line, where their drive stalled. On 3rd and 9 with 25 seconds left, Joe Flacco was sacked and fumbled, but the ball was recovered by Ben Grubbs. With the clock counting inside 10 seconds left and no timeouts, the field goal team managed to get into formation, and get the kick off. The 56 yard attempt by Billy Cundiff was dead center, but about 2 yards short. In overtime, the Steelers won the toss and got the ball, but were forced to punt. The Ravens, also forced to punt deep in their own territory, gave the ball to Pittsburgh around the Steeler 40 yard line. On a 3rd and 5, Dennis Dixon thew an interception to LB [[Paul Kruger (American football)|Paul Kruger]], who returned the ball 26 yards to the Steeler 28 yard line. Already in field goal range, the Ravens ran the ball down to the Pittsburgh 11 yard line where Billy Cundiff made a 29 yard field goal to win the game. With the win, both teams' records is 6â5. The Ravens hold the final wild card seed in the AFC due to the head-to-head tiebreaker over Pittsburgh. ====Week 13: at Green Bay Packers==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! All the Ravens needed was a win the following against the Oakland Raiders to clinch a playoff berth. ====Week 17: at Oakland Raiders==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="background:#BE00D2"|Week Seventeen: Baltimore Ravens vs. Oakland Raiders â Summary |- | {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * '''Game time:''' 4:15 PM EDT * '''Game weather:''' * '''Referee:''' [[Tony Corrente]] ;First Quarter * BAL- [[Willis McGahee|McGahee]] 2 yd TD run ([[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] PAT) â 3:47 ;Second Quarter * OAK- [[Sebastian Janikowski|Janikowski]] 37 yard FG â 14:49 * BAL- [[Willis McGahee|McGahee]] 77 yd TD run (Cundiff PAT) â 3:54 * OAK- [[Zach Miller|Miller]] 12 yard TD pass from [[Charlie Frye|Frye]] (Janikowski] PAT) â 0:47 ;Third Quarter * OAK- [[Sebastian Janikowski|Janikowski]] 39 yard FG â 4:06 ;Fourth Quarter * BAL- [[Willis McGahee|McGahee]] 2 yd TD run (Cundiff PAT) â 13:16 {{col-2}} * '''Game attendance:''' at [[Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum]] in [[Oakland, California]] * '''TV announcers:''' [[Jim Nantz]] & [[Phil Simms]] * '''Game coverage:''' [[CBS]] ;Leading Passers *OAK â [[Charlie Frye]] 18/25, 180 yards, 1 TD *BAL â [[Joe Flacco]] 11/19, 102 yards ;Leading Rushers *OAK â [[Michael Bush]] 10 carries, 18 yards *BAL â [[Willis McGahee]] 16 carries, 167 yards, 3 TD ;Leading Receivers *OAK â [[Chaz Schilens]] 8 catches, 99 yards *BAL â [[Todd Heap]] 2 catches, 40 yards ;Leading Tacklers *OAK â [[Kirk Morrison]] 9 tackles, 8 solo, 1 sack *BAL â [[Ray Lewis]] 8 tackles, 4 solo {{col-end}} |} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Ravens''' |R1=7 |R2=7 |R3=0 |R4=7 |RT=21 |Home=Raiders |H1=0 |H2=10 |H3=3 |H4=0 |HT=13 }} {{-}} This victory allowed the dethroning of the defending world champion [[2009 Pittsburgh Steelers season|Pittsburgh Steelers]] and ending the latter team's run at a repeat title. style="background:#BE00D2"|AFC Wild Card Round: Baltimore Ravens vs. New England Patriots â Summary |- | {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * '''Game time:''' 1:00 PM EDT * '''Game weather:''' * '''Referee:''' [[Gene Steratore]] ;First Quarter * BAL- [[Ray Rice|Rice]] 83 yd TD run ([[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] PAT) â 14:43 * BAL- [[Le'Ron McClain|McClain]] 1 yd TD run (Cundiff PAT) â 10:29 * BAL- [[Ray Rice|Rice]] 1 yd TD run (Cundiff PAT) â 3:55 * BAL- [[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] 27 yard FG â 1:19 ;Second Quarter * NE- [[Julian Edelman|Edelman]] 6 yd TD pass from [[Tom Brady|Brady]] ([[Stephen Gostkowski|Gostkowski]] PAT) â 11:23 ;Third Quarter * BAL- [[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] 23 yard FG â 6:18 * NE- [[Julian Edelman|Edelman]] 1 yd TD pass from [[Tom Brady|Brady]] (Gostkowski PAT) â 1:47 ;Fourth Quarter * BAL- [[Willis McGahee|McGahee]] 3 yd TD run (2 pt coversion NO GOOD) â 10:32 {{col-2}} * '''Game attendance:''' at [[Gillette Stadium]] in [[Foxborough, Massachusetts]] * '''TV announcers:''' ([[NFL on CBS|CBS]]) [[Jim Nantz]] & [[Phil Simms]] * '''Game coverage:''' ;Leading Passers *NE â [[Tom Brady]] 23/42, 154 yards, 2 TD, 3 INT *BAL â [[Joe Flacco]] 4/10, 34 yards, 1 INT ;Leading Rushers *NE â [[Kevin Faulk]] 14 carries, 52 yards *BAL â [[Ray Rice]] 22 carries, 159 yards, 2 TD ;Leading Receivers *NE â [[Randy Moss]] 5 catches, 48 yards *BAL â [[Mark Clayton (American football, born 1982)|Mark Clayton]] 1 catch, 17 yards ;Leading Tacklers *NE â [[Vince Wilfork]] 9 tackles, 5 solo *BAL â [[Domonique Foxworth]] 8 tackles, 7 solo {{col-end}} |} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Ravens''' |R1= 24 |R2= 0 |R3= 3 |R4= 6 |RT= 33 |Home=Patriots |H1= 0 |H2= 7 |H3= 7 |H4= 0 |HT= 14 |}} Entering the postseason as the AFC's sixth seed, the Ravens began their playoff run at [[Gillette Stadium]] in the AFC Wild Card round against the #3 seeded [[New England Patriots]]. This game was a rematch of their game played during Week 4 of the 2009 season. The Ravens drew first blood. As [[Ray Rice]] took the hand off from Flacco and ran through a hole in the Defense and on his way to a 83 yard TD! This was the on the Ravens' first offensive play of the game. It was the longest rush of his career and the 2nd longest rush in NFL postseason history.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/nfl/playbyplay?gameId=300110017|title=Baltimore 33, New England 14|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=12 January 2010}} Less than 2 minutes later, LB and DE [[Terrell Suggs]], forces a fumble from New England quarterback [[Tom Brady]]'s hand on a 3rd and 11 pass attempt and recovers for the Ravens on the New England 17. [[Le'Ron McClain]] then capped a 5 play Ravens scoring drive with a 2 yard touchdown plunge, extending the lead to 14â0. The Ravens capitalized on another New England miscue when cornerback [[Chris Carr (American football)|Chris Carr]] intercepted a Tom Brady pass. After a 6 play 26 yard drive Ray Rice hopped into the end-zone for his second touchdown of the quarter. On the Patriots very next possession another Tom Brady pass is intercepted by safety [[Ed Reed]]. Reed took the interception and returned it 25 yards before handing it off to Dawan Landry who took it another 25 yards. This led to leading to a Ravens field goal and a 24â0 first quarter lead. The Ravens went on to defeat the Patriots by a final score of 33â14. The Ravens would advance to face the top-seeded Colts in the Divisional Round. ====AFC Divisional Round: at Indianapolis Colts==== {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="background:#BE00D2"|AFC Divisional Round: Baltimore Ravens vs. Indianapolis Colts â Summary |- | {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * '''Game time:''' 8:15 PM EDT * '''Game weather:''' None (domed stadium) * '''Referee:''' [[Carl Cheffers]] ;First Quarter *IND â [[Matt Stover|Stover]] 44 yard FG â 10:44 *BAL â [[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] 25 yard FG â 2:57 ;Second Quarter *IND â [[Austin Collie|Collie]] 10 yard TD reception from [[Peyton Manning|Manning]] (Stover PAT) â 2:00 *IND â [[Reggie Wayne|Wayne]] 3-yard TD reception from Manning (Stover PAT) â 0:03 ;Third Quarter No Scoring ;Fourth Quarter *IND â Stover 33 yard FG â 13:26 {{col-2}} * '''Game attendance:''' 67,535 at [[Lucas Oil Stadium]] in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] * '''TV announcers ([[NFL on CBS|CBS]]):''' [[Greg Gumbel]] and [[Dan Dierdorf]] * '''Game coverage:''' [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54808/IND_Gamebook.pdf NFL Game Summary] ;Leading passers *IND â [[Peyton Manning]] 30 comp â 44 att â 246 yds â 2 TD â 1 INT *BAL â [[Joe Flacco]] 20 comp â 35 att â 189 yds â 0 TD â 2 INT ;Leading rushers *IND â [[Joseph Addai]] 11 rush â 23 yds â 0 TD *BAL â [[Ray Rice]] 13 rush â 67 yds â 0 TD ;Leading Receivers *IND â [[Reggie Wayne]] 8 rec â 63 yds â 1 TD *BAL â [[Ray Rice]] 9 rec â 60 yds â 0 TD ;Leading Tacklers *IND â [[Daniel Muir]] 7 tackles â 5 solo *BAL â [[Dannell Ellerbe]] 10 tackles â 10 solo {{col-end}} |} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Ravens |R1=3 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=0 |RT=3 |Home='''Colts''' |H1=3 |H2=14 |H3=0 |H4=3 |HT=20 |}} Coming off their impressive Wild Card road win over the Patriots, the Ravens flew to [[Lucas Oil Stadium]] for the AFC Divisional Round against the top-seeded [[Indianapolis Colts]]. Baltimore would trail to begin the first quarter as former Ravens kicker [[Matt Stover]] got a 44-yard field goal. The Ravens would respond with kicker [[Billy Cundiff]] making a 25-yard field goal. However, the Colts rebounded in the second quarter as quarterback [[Peyton Manning]] completed a 10-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Austin Collie]] and a 3-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Reggie Wayne]]. Following a scoreless third quarter, Baltimore's deficit increased in the fourth quarter as Stover gave Indianapolis a 33-yard field goal. With the loss, the Ravens' season ended with an overall record of 10â8. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.baltimoreravens.com/ Official website] *[http://www.nfl.com/teams/baltimoreravens/profile?team=BAL NFL.com profile] *[http://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/rav/2009.htm 2009 Baltimore Ravens season at Pro Football Reference] *[http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/teams/schedule?team=bal 2009 Baltimore Ravens season at ESPN] {{Baltimore Ravens}} {{Baltimore Ravens seasons}} {{2009 NFL season by team}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2009 Baltimore Ravens Season}} [[Category:2009 National Football League season by team|Baltimore]] [[Category:Baltimore Ravens seasons]]
